values.reason: New pull request to other target

values.title: Support for bullet and ODE in heightmap tests

values.description:
A test is added to gazebo/physics/Joint_TEST.cc that Spawns a joint of each type using all available physics engines. It spawns joints connecting real links, as well as connecting to the world as a parent and child.

I also fix a seg-fault when trying to connect a revolute2 joint to the world, which does not work in ODE.

Note that this doesn't actually test the functionality of each joint, but just that the functions don't seg-fault when trying to create each type of joint.

Targeted to gazebo_1.9 since there aren't any API changes.
values.title: SpawnJoint tests for ODE and bullet

summary.raw:
A test is added to gazebo/physics/Joint_TEST.cc that Spawns a joint of each type using all available physics engines. It spawns joints connecting real links, as well as connecting to the world as a parent and child.

I also fix a seg-fault when trying to connect a revolute2 joint to the world, which does not work in ODE.

Note that this doesn't actually test the functionality of each joint, but just that the functions don't seg-fault when trying to create each type of joint.

Targeted to gazebo_1.9 since there aren't any API changes.
summary.html:
A test is added to gazebo/physics/Joint_TEST.cc that Spawns a joint of each type using all available physics engines. It spawns joints connecting real links, as well as connecting to the world as a parent and child.

I also fix a seg-fault when trying to connect a revolute2 joint to the world, which does not work in ODE.

Note that this doesn't actually test the functionality of each joint, but just that the functions don't seg-fault when trying to create each type of joint.

Targeted to gazebo_1.9 since there aren't any API changes.

values.description:
This implementation of `SetVelocity()` is still incomplete, but should be correct for the common case of wheels.

Also added bullet variant of pioneer2dx straight line test.

values.title: Merge 1.9 back to default
Fix warning in default branch caused by resolution of issue #775

values.description:
This pull request will allow the gazebo_1.9 branch to compile under Mac OS X. There are still bugs (notably #800, #802), and I haven't verified that all tests pass, but it's a start.

This pull request includes an assortment of compilation fixes, warning fixes for default apple compiler, and fixes for regression tests. There's no API changes, so it should be safe for 1.9.

To test on osx, you'll first need the xcode developer tools. These can be downloaded from the App Store or the [Apple developer website](https://developer.apple.com).

You'll also need to get the dependencies, and [Homebrew](http://brew.sh) is the easiest way to get them.
~~~
# To install homebrew:
ruby -e "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.github.com/mxcl/homebrew/go)"
# Update your list of formula
brew update
# The following will warn you if there are problems with your configuration
# and possibly recommend changes
brew doctor
# Use custom formulae from ROS for some dependencies
brew tap ros/groovy
# or equivalently
brew tap ros/hydro
# install the dependencies
brew install `brew deps --1 gazebo`
~~~
values.title: OSX support for gazebo 1.9

summary.html:
This pull request will allow the gazebo_1.9 branch to compile under Mac OS X. There are still bugs (notably #800, #802), and I haven't verified that all tests pass, but it's a start.

This pull request includes an assortment of compilation fixes, warning fixes for default apple compiler, and fixes for regression tests. There's no API changes, so it should be safe for 1.9.

To test on osx, you'll first need the xcode developer tools. These can be downloaded from the App Store or the Apple developer website.

You'll also need to get the dependencies, and Homebrew is the easiest way to get them.

# To install homebrew:
ruby -e "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.github.com/mxcl/homebrew/go)"
# Update your list of formula
brew update
# The following will warn you if there are problems with your configuration
# and possibly recommend changes
brew doctor
# Use custom formulae from ROS for some dependencies
brew tap ros/groovy
# or equivalently
brew tap ros/hydro
# install the dependencies
brew install `brew deps --1 gazebo`

values.description: Followed Carlos's example in the heightmap test.
values.title: Switched ode/bullet tests to value-parameterized tests

summary.raw: Followed Carlos's example in the heightmap test.
summary.html: Followed Carlos's example in the heightmap test.

values.description: The implementation of `BulletHingeJoint::SetVelocity` wasn't checking the `parentLink` pointer to see if it existed. This pointer will be null when a joint is connected to the world. This has been causing test failures ([one example](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-quantal-amd64/280/testReport/%28root%29/INTEGRATION_physics/test_ran/)). This is a simple fix.
values.title: Fix PhysicsTest.SimplePendulumBullet

summary.raw: The implementation of `BulletHingeJoint::SetVelocity` wasn't checking the `parentLink` pointer to see if it existed. This pointer will be null when a joint is connected to the world. This has been causing test failures ([one example](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-quantal-amd64/280/testReport/%28root%29/INTEGRATION_physics/test_ran/)). This is a simple fix.
summary.html: The implementation of BulletHingeJoint::SetVelocity wasn't checking the parentLink pointer to see if it existed. This pointer will be null when a joint is connected to the world. This has been causing test failures (one example). This is a simple fix.

values.description:
**Includes pull request #661.  Review and merge that one first.**

All the tests in `test/regression` for which the physics engine would seem to have an effect have been moved to the value-parameterized test pattern, with both ode and bullet variants.  I didn't do this for tests that seem to be physics-independent, such as transport and GPU tests.

There remain a few tests that don't have bullet variants, because they don't pass (grepping for `TEST_F` is a good start for finding tests that aren't parameterized):

~~~
physics.cc:TEST_F(PhysicsTest, JointDampingTest)
physics.cc:TEST_F(PhysicsTest, DropStuff)
physics.cc:TEST_F(PhysicsTest, CollisionTest)
surface_properties.cc:TEST_F(PhysicsTest, CollideWithoutContact)
~~~
values.title: Add a handful of missing Bullet test variants

All the tests in `test/regression` for which the physics engine would seem to have an effect have been moved to the value-parameterized test pattern, with both ode and bullet variants.  I didn't do this for tests that seem to be physics-independent, such as transport and GPU tests.

There remain a few tests that don't have bullet variants, because they don't pass (grepping for `TEST_F` is a good start for finding tests that aren't parameterized):

summary.html:
Includes pull request #661. Review and merge that one first.

All the tests in test/regression for which the physics engine would seem to have an effect have been moved to the value-parameterized test pattern, with both ode and bullet variants. I didn't do this for tests that seem to be physics-independent, such as transport and GPU tests.

There remain a few tests that don't have bullet variants, because they don't pass (grepping for TEST_F is a good start for finding tests that aren't parameterized):

values.description:
I've added a test for the message-passing interface used by the GUI move tool. I also threw in a test for setting the gravity value via the message passing interface.

I'm open to suggestions for the name of the test file. It's currently called `test/regression/gui_test.cc`.
values.title: Added test for GUI move tool

I'm open to suggestions for the name of the test file. It's currently called `test/regression/gui_test.cc`.

values.description: Sometimes the test suite is going to be run in a different machine than the one which is compiling the code. This pull request implements an option to not use the checks and compile all test suite.

values.description:
This is a simple tool that will give info about open pull requests and also the list of changed files in a specific pull request.

Invoking the command with no arguments gives a list of up to 10 open pull requests. The numeric id is given in the first column, followed by the changeset hash and the branch name.
~~~
$ tools/bitbucket_pullrequests 
669	35efa6e05325	code_check_refactor
666	0e5d72cca63f	cppcheck_manpages_fixes
667	c5dc43b38144	force_graphic_support
648	5e4847610672	openal
644	7b889ca99caa	wireless
561	5873d6c048aa	pref_nate
647	c883014ede8e	gps_sensor
634	67ab0d4d2875	gui_interaction
607	75ba4e5f7a23	sensor_update_rate
581	517ed0f039d5	spheres_links_question
~~~

Invoking the command with a single numeric argument will return the list of changed files for that pull request.
~~~
$ tools/bitbucket_pullrequests 648
cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake
gazebo/common/AudioDecoder.cc
gazebo/common/AudioDecoder.hh
gazebo/common/AudioDecoder_TEST.cc
gazebo/common/CMakeLists.txt
gazebo/common/CommonIface.cc
gazebo/common/CommonIface.hh
gazebo/common/Video.cc
gazebo/gazebo.cc
gazebo/msgs/link.proto
gazebo/physics/Collision.cc
gazebo/physics/Link.cc
gazebo/physics/Link.hh
gazebo/physics/Model.cc
gazebo/physics/Model.hh
gazebo/physics/World.cc
gazebo/physics/bullet/BulletLink.cc
gazebo/physics/bullet/BulletLink.hh
gazebo/physics/ode/ODELink.cc
gazebo/physics/ode/ODELink.hh
gazebo/rendering/Heightmap.cc
gazebo/rendering/RenderEngine.cc
gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc
gazebo/rendering/deferred_shading/MergeMaterialGenerator.cc
gazebo/sdf/1.4/CMakeLists.txt
gazebo/sdf/1.4/audio_sink.sdf
gazebo/sdf/1.4/audio_source.sdf
gazebo/sdf/1.4/link.sdf
gazebo/sdf/1.4/world.sdf
gazebo/sensors/RFIDTag.cc
gazebo/util/CMakeLists.txt
gazebo/util/OpenAL.cc
gazebo/util/OpenAL.hh
gazebo/util/OpenAL_TEST.cc
gazebo/util/UtilTypes.hh
media/audio/CMakeLists.txt
sdf/worlds/CMakeLists.txt
sdf/worlds/openal.world
~~~

It should be a simple extension to run `tools/code_check.sh` against the changed files.

UPDATE: As of b476e49, the tool will print info for all open pull requests (not just the first 10).

values.description:
I've updated the bitbucker_pullrequest tool to have the following syntax:
~~~
$ bitbucket_pullrequests
Usage: bitbucket_pullrequests [options]
    -l, --list                       List open pull requests with fields:
                                     [id] [source] [dest] [branch]
    -s, --summary [id]               Summarize a pull request with fields:
                                     [id] [source] [dest] [branch]
    -c, --check [id]
    -f, --files [id]                 Show changed files in a pull request
    -h, --help                       Display this help message
~~~
~~~
$ bitbucket_pullrequests --list
  671    2beb52994344    de26348acac4    pullrequest_analysis
  634    a29eb4e20f24    de26348acac4    gui_interaction
  677    6df898525e5e    de26348acac4    osx_menubar
  680    96614934a358    de26348acac4    remove_internal_sdf
  561    a4569d964211    de26348acac4    pref_nate
  678    1b77d8f23a04    40d346454df0    gazebo_1.9
  673    d1f301d03fa1    de26348acac4    force_torque_test
  675    2b025a23303d    de26348acac4    wireless
  607    1e3e8158506a    de26348acac4    sensor_update_rate
  581    517ed0f039d5    7f3c8f2de150    spheres_links_question
~~~
~~~
$ bitbucket_pullrequests --summary 648
  648    8abe4e700683    47728f25191b    openal
~~~
~~~
$ bitbucket_pullrequests --files 648
cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake
gazebo/common/AudioDecoder.cc
gazebo/common/AudioDecoder.hh
gazebo/common/AudioDecoder_TEST.cc
gazebo/common/CMakeLists.txt
…
test/regression/pr2.cc
test/regression/server_fixture.cc
test/regression/speed.cc
test/regression/speed_pr2.cc
~~~
I've also added an option to do a quick code check on the changed files with `-c` or `--check`. The only requirement for this option is that you invoke `bitbucket_pullrequests` from within a gazebo mercurial repository. It will tell you if you need to `hg pull`, and it won't touch the local files; it will `hg cat` to a temporary file and check that file.

I'm open to suggestions on the names for these tools.
values.title: Update pull request tool and add quick_check script

cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake
gazebo/common/AudioDecoder.cc
gazebo/common/AudioDecoder.hh
gazebo/common/AudioDecoder_TEST.cc
gazebo/common/CMakeLists.txt
…
test/regression/pr2.cc
test/regression/server_fixture.cc
test/regression/speed.cc
test/regression/speed_pr2.cc

I've also added an option to do a quick code check on the changed files with -c or --check. The only requirement for this option is that you invoke bitbucket_pullrequests from within a gazebo mercurial repository. It will tell you if you need to hg pull, and it won't touch the local files; it will hg cat to a temporary file and check that file.

I'm open to suggestions on the names for these tools.

values.description:
A test is added to Joint_TEST that spawns joints that don't allow translation and verifies that the attached bodies are appropriately constrained.

I fixed BulletBallJoint and BulletUniversalJoint so they can pass this test. I also made some fixes to BulletHinge2Joint, though it is not included in this test, since it allows translation along an axis.
values.title: Add test for rotational joints, fix some bullet joints

values.description:
Add an option to `gztopic echo` that prints messages on a single line, which is useful for command-line parsing.

Currently `gztopic echo /gazebo/default/world_stats` outputs human-readable formatting with messages on multiple lines:
~~~
sim_time {
  sec: 17
  nsec: 218000000
}
pause_time {
  sec: 0
  nsec: 0
}
real_time {
  sec: 17
  nsec: 363079642
}
paused: false
iterations: 17218

sim_time {
  sec: 17
  nsec: 413000000
}
pause_time {
  sec: 0
  nsec: 0
}
real_time {
  sec: 17
  nsec: 563192487
}
paused: false
iterations: 17413
~~~

With this pull request, `gztopic echo -u /gazebo/default/world_stats` would output the following, with each message on a single line:
~~~
sim_time { sec: 197 nsec: 357000000 } pause_time { sec: 0 nsec: 0 } real_time { sec: 198 nsec: 846875458 } paused: false iterations: 197357
sim_time { sec: 197 nsec: 557000000 } pause_time { sec: 0 nsec: 0 } real_time { sec: 199 nsec: 47136552 } paused: false iterations: 197557
sim_time { sec: 197 nsec: 757000000 } pause_time { sec: 0 nsec: 0 } real_time { sec: 199 nsec: 247788813 } paused: false iterations: 197757
~~~
This lets you do fun command-line filtering. For example, if you want to output csv, you can use the following:
~~~
gztopic echo /gazebo/default/world_stats -u | \
  sed -e 's@[a-zA-Z_\{\}:]*@@g' -e 's@^ *@@' -e 's@  *@,@g'
~~~
~~~
201,576000000,0,0,202,185685673,201576
201,776000000,0,0,202,386284097,201776
201,977000000,0,0,202,587381368,201977
~~~
I also removed a bit of code that attempted to take program arguments from stdin. This was causing problems (issue #795), so this should fix that issue.
values.title: Simplify command-line parsing of gztopic echo output and fix #795

summary.html:
Add an option to gztopic echo that prints messages on a single line, which is useful for command-line parsing.

Currently gztopic echo /gazebo/default/world_stats outputs human-readable formatting with messages on multiple lines:

sim_time {
  sec: 17
  nsec: 218000000
}
pause_time {
  sec: 0
  nsec: 0
}
real_time {
  sec: 17
  nsec: 363079642
}
paused: false
iterations: 17218

sim_time {
  sec: 17
  nsec: 413000000
}
pause_time {
  sec: 0
  nsec: 0
}
real_time {
  sec: 17
  nsec: 563192487
}
paused: false
iterations: 17413

With this pull request, gztopic echo -u /gazebo/default/world_stats would output the following, with each message on a single line:

sim_time { sec: 197 nsec: 357000000 } pause_time { sec: 0 nsec: 0 } real_time { sec: 198 nsec: 846875458 } paused: false iterations: 197357
sim_time { sec: 197 nsec: 557000000 } pause_time { sec: 0 nsec: 0 } real_time { sec: 199 nsec: 47136552 } paused: false iterations: 197557
sim_time { sec: 197 nsec: 757000000 } pause_time { sec: 0 nsec: 0 } real_time { sec: 199 nsec: 247788813 } paused: false iterations: 197757

This lets you do fun command-line filtering. For example, if you want to output csv, you can use the following:

gztopic echo /gazebo/default/world_stats -u | \
  sed -e 's@[a-zA-Z_\{\}:]*@@g' -e 's@^ *@@' -e 's@  *@,@g'

201,576000000,0,0,202,185685673,201576
201,776000000,0,0,202,386284097,201776
201,977000000,0,0,202,587381368,201977

I also removed a bit of code that attempted to take program arguments from stdin. This was causing problems (issue #795), so this should fix that issue.

values.description:
Replace the literal references to UNIX directories by cmake variables from GNUInstallDirs. This will allow us to abstract about the proper location to place binaries and some other data and probably can help with migration to other UNIX platforms such as OsX or BSD.

Proposed and info supplied by @thomas_moulard (thanks). Not sure if something is still missing to be migrated.
values.title: Migrate UNIX directories to use GNUInstallDirs cmake macro

summary.raw:
Replace the literal references to UNIX directories by cmake variables from GNUInstallDirs. This will allow us to abstract about the proper location to place binaries and some other data and probably can help with migration to other UNIX platforms such as OsX or BSD.

Proposed and info supplied by @thomas_moulard (thanks). Not sure if something is still missing to be migrated.

values.description:
Renamed `test/regression` to `test/integration`. Made a new `test/regression` directory. Quoting Jose, "Regression tests are those originated by bugs appearing after the software is released, and usually directly linked to a bug report. Let's say: for bitbucket #871 issue we could have a regression test with filename something like:

`871_gazebo-init-not-called-before-sdf-parser_TEST.cc`".

values.description:
Issue #236 had been fixed but regressed and wasn't captured by the current test. I've updated the test to capture the regression and fixed the problem (Sensors stopped updating after Reset World). The main issue was that `SensorManager::SimTimeEventHandler` (used in [SensorContainer::RunLoop](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/9ad03400ac953b5702ba8181d54f2fd1aab6f566/gazebo/sensors/SensorManager.cc#cl-513)) wasn't responding to the reset time signals. So I add a `this->runCondition.notify_one()` to `SensorContainer::ResetLastUpdateTimes` and added a mutex for good measure. The updated test now passes.

While I was fixing tests, I noticed that the contact_sensor test has been failing 100% of the time (#796). The test involves placing a sphere on top of a box, and for some reason this causes the ODE contact to be very noisy. I changed the `min_depth` on the box to 5 mm, and it is fixed.
values.title: Fix regression of #236, also contact_sensor test #796

summary.raw:
Issue #236 had been fixed but regressed and wasn't captured by the current test. I've updated the test to capture the regression and fixed the problem (Sensors stopped updating after Reset World). The main issue was that `SensorManager::SimTimeEventHandler` (used in [SensorContainer::RunLoop](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/9ad03400ac953b5702ba8181d54f2fd1aab6f566/gazebo/sensors/SensorManager.cc#cl-513)) wasn't responding to the reset time signals. So I add a `this->runCondition.notify_one()` to `SensorContainer::ResetLastUpdateTimes` and added a mutex for good measure. The updated test now passes.

While I was fixing tests, I noticed that the contact_sensor test has been failing 100% of the time (#796). The test involves placing a sphere on top of a box, and for some reason this causes the ODE contact to be very noisy. I changed the `min_depth` on the box to 5 mm, and it is fixed.
summary.html:
Issue #236 had been fixed but regressed and wasn't captured by the current test. I've updated the test to capture the regression and fixed the problem (Sensors stopped updating after Reset World). The main issue was that SensorManager::SimTimeEventHandler (used in SensorContainer::RunLoop) wasn't responding to the reset time signals. So I add a this->runCondition.notify_one() to SensorContainer::ResetLastUpdateTimes and added a mutex for good measure. The updated test now passes.

While I was fixing tests, I noticed that the contact_sensor test has been failing 100% of the time (#796). The test involves placing a sphere on top of a box, and for some reason this causes the ODE contact to be very noisy. I changed the min_depth on the box to 5 mm, and it is fixed.

values.description: In our recent changes to `ServerFixture`, we added a `const char *` as a parameter type, but we should allow other parameter types as well (see #820 for some discussion). This pull request removes the parameter specification from ServerFixture and allows derived test fixtures to specify which parameters they would like to use.
values.title: Issue #820 part 1, allow different gtest parameter types with ServerFixture

summary.raw: In our recent changes to `ServerFixture`, we added a `const char *` as a parameter type, but we should allow other parameter types as well (see #820 for some discussion). This pull request removes the parameter specification from ServerFixture and allows derived test fixtures to specify which parameters they would like to use.
summary.html: In our recent changes to ServerFixture, we added a const char * as a parameter type, but we should allow other parameter types as well (see #820 for some discussion). This pull request removes the parameter specification from ServerFixture and allows derived test fixtures to specify which parameters they would like to use.

values.description:
The Ogre terrain paging capabilities have been integrated in Gazebo. A heightmap terrain is decomposed in several subterrains that can be loaded/unloaded depending on the camera distance. It depends on sdformat pull request [#47](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/47/add-element-inside-heightmap/diff).

It can be tested using sdf/worlds/heightmap.world. Do not forget to change the <use_terrain_paging> element to true in the world file.
values.title: Terrain paging support for rendering

summary.raw:
The Ogre terrain paging capabilities have been integrated in Gazebo. A heightmap terrain is decomposed in several subterrains that can be loaded/unloaded depending on the camera distance. It depends on sdformat pull request [#47](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/47/add-element-inside-heightmap/diff).

It can be tested using sdf/worlds/heightmap.world. Do not forget to change the <use_terrain_paging> element to true in the world file.
summary.html:
The Ogre terrain paging capabilities have been integrated in Gazebo. A heightmap terrain is decomposed in several subterrains that can be loaded/unloaded depending on the camera distance. It depends on sdformat pull request #47.

It can be tested using sdf/worlds/heightmap.world. Do not forget to change the <use_terrain_paging> element to true in the world file.

values.description:
In pull request #671, I updated the code_check script to evaluate additional testing folders, but I did not run the updated code check script, so there were several errors, but they are fixed here. Most of them are whitespace; one is an unused variable in physics_msgs.cc, and another is a complaint about using unsigned long instead of explicit integer sizing.

http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-raring-amd64/78/cppcheckResult/?

values.title: Add test for rotational joints, fix some bullet joints, #820

summary.html:
This is a re-try of pull request #672 that uses some fancy gtest syntax to allow for multiple parameters to tests (issue #820). Using multiple parameters requires use of the std::tr1::tuple datatype. For example, two strings can be represented by a tuple and accessed as:

typedef std::tr1::tuple<std::string, std::string> std_string2;
std_string2 param;
std_string string1 string2;
std::tr1::tie(string1, string2) = param;

Then you can use the gtest Combine function (see Joint_TEST.cc) to run tests against all combinations of lists of parameters (aka Cartesian product).

I did all that in order to add some joint tests, which required fixing some bullet joints. I also refactored helper_physics_generator based on the syntax of the Combine function.

values.description:
Originally started due to reasons explained in #!/osrf/gazebo-release/issue/31/do-not-assume-that-binary-to-generate-is thanks to @thomas_moulard

This pull request introduce two new building variables which control the generation of:

* Host dependant CFlags ```USE_HOST_CFLAGS``` (Host SEE support)
* Default gazebo development flags ```USE_UPSTREAM_CFLAGS```

For historical reasons, I've left both enabled by defaut.

If both are disabled, it should generate cmake default clfags or system/user provided flags.
values.title: Use variables to control auto generation of CFlags

summary.raw:
Originally started due to reasons explained in #!/osrf/gazebo-release/issue/31/do-not-assume-that-binary-to-generate-is thanks to @thomas_moulard

This pull request introduce two new building variables which control the generation of:

* Host dependant CFlags ```USE_HOST_CFLAGS``` (Host SEE support)
* Default gazebo development flags ```USE_UPSTREAM_CFLAGS```

For historical reasons, I've left both enabled by defaut.

If both are disabled, it should generate cmake default clfags or system/user provided flags.
summary.html:
Originally started due to reasons explained in #!/osrf/gazebo-release/issue/31/do-not-assume-that-binary-to-generate-is thanks to @thomas_moulard

This pull request introduce two new building variables which control the generation of:

  • Host dependant CFlags USE_HOST_CFLAGS (Host SEE support)
  • Default gazebo development flags USE_UPSTREAM_CFLAGS

For historical reasons, I've left both enabled by defaut.

If both are disabled, it should generate cmake default clfags or system/user provided flags.
